name: 勞維俊
objective: 課程橫跨英國文學的歷史，由中世紀到現代， 選讀英國文學史中最經典、最耐讀、可讀性最高的作品。務求由社會背境、歷史脈絡、和哲學思潮各方面理解作品。目標除了對英國文學史，不同文類（詩、戲劇、小說）和文學技巧有較全面的認識外，更可以提升理解其他文學作品的能力。
schedule:
Course Aims:

This course offers a directed sampling of a range of literary texts across the history of British literature, from the medieval to the modern period. Canonical works of different literary genres (poetry, drama, novel) will be discussed in relation to their social, historical and philosophical backgrounds. Upon completion of the course, participants should have a basic understanding of the history of British literature, and be able to identify their corresponding styles and literary devices, cultural and philosophical issues.

Course Outline: 

1. Introduction　　: overview and examples, selected poems from:
Blake, ‘The Tyger’, ‘The Sick Rose’, ‘London’
Dickens, Bleak House (ch.1) 

2-3. Romantic poetry:
Keats, ‘Ode to a Nightingale’, ‘Ode on a Grecian Urn’, ‘Ode to Autumn’, ‘Ode on Melancholy’. 
Coleridge, ‘Kubla Khan, or, A Vision in a Dream. A Fragment’ and ‘The Rime of the Ancient Mariner’ 
Wordsworth, ‘Michael,’ ‘There Was a Boy,’ and ‘Preface to the Lyrical Ballads’ (1802)

4-5. Literature and the fantastic: 
* Robert Louis Stevenson, Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde (1886) 
- Freud, ‘The “Uncanny”’

6-8. Elizabethan Renaissance theatre 
* Shakespeare, Othello or Julius Caesar
- Sonnets (No. 30, 66, 116)

9. Mid-term exam 

10. Seventeenth-century poetry: 
Andrew Marvell, ‘An Horatian Ode upon Cromwell’s Return from Ireland,’ ‘To His coy Mistress,’ ‘The Garden,’ and ‘Upon Appleton House’ (extract)
- John Donne
- George Herbert 
- T.S. Eliot on Marvell

11. Augustan poetry
- Alexander Pope, Epistle to Dr Arbuthnot (1735) 
- Samuel Johnson, ‘The Vanity of Human Wishes: The Tenth Satire of Juvenal Imitated’ (1749) and ‘On the Death of Dr Robert Levet’

12-14. Detailed studies: Dickens’ Great Expectations  
* Dickens, Great Expectations  (1860-1)
- Dickens, Hard Times (ch.1)
- Thomas Carlyle, Signs of the Times (extract)
- Freud, Beyond the Pleasure Principle 
- Peter Brooks, Reading for the Plot

15-16. Reading the Modernist poems
T.S. Eliot, ‘The Waste Land’ (1922)
- Shakespeare, The Tempest  (extract)
- Dante, Inferno (Canto 1) and Purgatorio  (Canto 26)
- Pound, ‘Cathay’ or ‘Station in a Station of a Metro’

17. Postmodernist play
Samuel Becket’s Endgame (1957)

18. Final Essay due
scorePolicy:
Teaching Approach (tentative):

The students are expected to have read the required primary texts before the lecture. Classes will be in the form of lectures and tutorials (2-hour lecture and 1-hour tutorial per week). Assessments include tutorial participation, group presentation, mid-term test, and essay writing.

Assessment: 

Tutorial participation 　　　　10%
Presentation 　　　　　　　　20%
Mid-term test　　　　　　　　30%
Final Essay　　　　　　　　40% (drafts 10%, final revision 30%)

NOTE: Please make sure your works are original and contain no unacknowledged materials. Plagiarism is an offense in the academic field, and Taipei takes it very seriously. The minimum penalty for plagiarism is a straight Fail in the course and the case may be passed on to the university for record.
